paragraph.name: Introduction
paragraph.desc: Describe the subject of the data

notes.para: Chart: percentage of UK electricity 2011-2015 supplied by renewables, gas, coal, nuclear and other

content.para: The chart shows the percentage of electricity supplied by five types of energy source in the UK between 2011 and 2015: renewables (solar, wind, tidal and hydro), gas, coal, nuclear, and other sources (e.g. biofuels).

paragraph.name: Development
paragraph.desc: Make a general comment on the trends shown in the data and explain the main trend with supporting detail.

notes.para: Level of all types of supply changed.
Renewables: biggest changeâ€”from 10% of total to 25%

para.extra_info: In this period all five types of supply changed to some extent, but the most significant change was in the renewable category.

At the beginning of the period the percentage of electricity supplied by renewables was the second lowest at just under 10 per cent. Over the four-year period this more than doubled to 25 per cent. This made it the second most common source of electricity after gas, which in 2015 supplied 30 per cent of the market.

paragraph.name: Comparing and contrasting trends
paragraph.desc: Explain other similar trends and give details. Compare and contrast these trends with others.
paragraph.tip: TIP The number of paragraphs you use will depend on the amount of data you are writing about.

notes.para: Gas most common but fell (40% to 30%). Coal fell most (39% to 23%). Nuclear rose (19% to 21%).
Biofuels remained low with little change.

content.para: Over the whole period gas remained the most common source of electricity. However, the percentage it supplied dropped from 40 per cent to 30 per cent, having fallen to a low of 27 per cent in 2013. The other category that fell over the same period was coal, which had the most dramatic fall from 39 per cent in 2012 to 23 per cent in 2015. At the same time the percentage of nuclear power went up slightly, from 19 per cent to 21 per cent. If these trends in coal and nuclear supply continue, nuclear will overtake coal in the next few years. Other sources of electricity such as biofuels remained at a relatively low percentage and did not change significantly over the four-year period.

paragraph.name: Conclusion
paragraph.desc: Draw together the main trends identified in the report.

notes.para: Pattern of electricity sources changed signifcantly.
Main trends: drop in coal, rise in renewables

content.para: In conclusion, the chart shows that the pattern of electricity sources changed significantly in the categories of renewables, gas and coal over the period 2011 to 2015. The most significant trends were the drop in coal and the rise in renewables.
